measured_by: child-friendly food token allocation task with 12 tokens across single vs. double animal boxes
justification: The study recounts that “Children were given 12 ‘food’ tokens to distribute to four different types of zoo animals displayed across three boxes… an influence of the arbitrary three-way box partition… is evidence of partition dependence.”

measured_by: child-friendly food token allocation task with 5 tokens across single vs. double animal boxes
justification: Experiment 2 states that participants “were given only five food tokens to distribute to the animals,” and that allocating more than half the tokens to the single-animal boxes was used to detect partition dependence.

measured_by: financial aid allocation task involving partitioned income brackets
justification: The article reports that Fox, Bardolet et al. (2005) “asked graduate students to allocate limited financial aid resources to recipients in different household incomes and found that financial aid allocations were influenced by the partitioning of income brackets,” evidencing partition dependence.

measured_by: vignette-based antibiotic prescription choice task with partitioned medication menus
justification: Tannenbaum et al. (2015) showed that “Primary care providers chose aggressive treatments significantly more often when they were listed individually, compared to when they were grouped together,” demonstrating partition dependence measured through the partitioned antibiotic menu.

measured_by: hypothetical wine selection task with wines grouped by country versus grape type
justification: The text notes that “when wine descriptions were grouped by country of origin, participants diversified their selections over country of origin, but when descriptions were grouped by type of grape, they diversified their selections over type of grape instead,” illustrating diversification bias via this wine selection task.
